												I gave this game a shot, I really did. I wanted to like it, and even with it's obvious, glaring flaws, I dug deeper to see if there was something there, but after it was all said and done, there wasn't.The game presents an interesting idea, and it reminded me of something like Dungeon Keeper. You have dwarves, and you have them mine these caves for you in real-time, collecting resources, which you use to attack the other team. You can find treasures, and different items that give you temporary upgrades for that match, and eventually, one team becomes the victor.Sound great, right? Well, no, actually.On paper, the game sounds like it'd be cool, and really fun, but in practice, the controls are just awful. You're forced to move the camera around by clicking and dragging, and issuing commands to your units just feels really cumbersome. The artstyle is interesting for a bit, but once you realize how limited the whole thing is, and how many assets they changed the colors on and re-used. that also begins to lose it's appeal. There is basically no storyline to speak of, and what little bit of flavor text they do try to put in there just comes off as bland and annoying.I could forgive ALL of these things if the design of the game was fun... but it also fails in that aspect. Nothing I did in the game felt rewarding or satisfying, and I think that's the most damning thing you can say about it. It just feels like a bunch of cumbersome clicking without any payoff. It's a bland, useless, mess of a game, and nobody should waste their time or money with it.

												Delve Deeper is a game about dwarven greed. But mostly TREASURE! Go down there and grab as much as you can for your most exhalted king. And more importantly, get more than the other teams!You'll go in with five(5) dwarves, and will need to collect as much loot as you can in games that seem to go by pretty quickly. It's a simple game with solid mechanics, where you start your turn with a tunnel piece you can put down somewhere to expand your tunnels, or to unleash a massive horde of goblins into your opponent's tunnels. After that, you move your dwarves and end your turn. After that you fight with whichever dwarves are in tiles with enemies on them. A simple and easy to learn system with plenty of maps and plenty of replayability. And on top of that, it's cheap tooWorth grabbing whenever you have some cash left over for it. It's cheap, amusing to play, has plenty of replayability(So long as you don't play it all the time) and a most worthy king to deliver all your gold to who occasionally comments on things going on in his own special kind of way.

												Delve Deeper is a local 1-4 player game where you play against each other to try to get the most treasure. At the beginning of the game, you choose from 4 different coloured dwarf mining teams (red, blue, green, yellow), each consisting of 5 dwarfs. At the start of your turn, you can choose a tile from the right side which basically causes one area of the map to be auto-mined, creating a tunnel. Once the tile has been placed, you can move some or all of your dwarfs, having them pick up treasure, mine for gold, and fight monsters or other dwarves. When a dwarf's inventory is full, you direct them to go back to base to off load their treasure. Rinse and repeat until the game is finished.This is a very simple game, and it's actually pretty fun. Until it crashes. And it crashes a lot. In fact, looking at the forums and other reviews, it seems that this bug has been in the game from the very beginning and in two years since the game's release on Steam, the developers still haven't fixed it. Until this bug is fixed, I can not recommend this game.

												Delve Deeper was a little confusing at first, but after spending an hour learning the ropes, I found the game does offer some mild fun. It's a short turn-based strategy game where you and up to three other players control a team of dwarfs and compete against one another in search for the most treasure. There's a handful of different treasure types that are worth different points plus collectible relics which can modify your team member's stats. Each game is played for a finite amount of turns (usually between 10 and 30) and the player with the most points after all turns are played wins. Nothing over the top--just short and simple. It's a very similar game style to Worms.There are three classes of dwarfs each having different stats like hit points, movement points, and inventory slots which you choose before the match. Each team starts at a different mining location allowing you to decide whether to battle your opponents and take their stuff or avoid them and just mine for gold. There is also an evil team which is computer controlled made up of various monsters throughout the dungeon to thwart your treasure collecting efforts. The old school battle system works pretty well with the rest of the game's simplicity.Now there are a couple game breaking bugs that you'll need to avoid otherwise the game will just crash. When you are on an invalid dig location and click on the yellow area where it says "No Valid Plays", the game will crash. Very repeatable and very annoying, but if you don't click on the yellow area, the game seems to be stable. Also you'll want to turn off the tutorial, otherwise the game randomly locks up during some battle sequences. I found a few forum posts about these plus claims that the developers have moved on to a sequel so there likely won't be any future fixes.If you can work around these bugs, the game isn't bad. I can't really recommend a game with major lingering bugs, but there is a decent amount of replayability for fun in small doses.

												Delve Deeper is a game which on the surface seems cute and innocent.  However, below the exterior is a game which is deceptively difficult and unendingly fun.Is the ultimate goal is to make more money for your king than the other team.  You will need to excavate tunnels in order to get at the wealth which is hidden from view.  Where will you dig your tunnels, and what strategy will you use when placing them in order to find the greatest amount of wealth?There are all manner of nasty things down there which are just waiting to be released so that they can attack your Miners.  Usually they guard large amounts of wealth or the entryways two areas which you need in order to be able to, of course, delve deeper which is where the best of the loot is to be found.  The questions here are, do you risk the attack, and if you do, how many of your Miners will you commit to the battle?  Your Miners can't be killed, but they can get beat up so badly that they will miss the next turn.  That can end up in the cycle where your miner is being killed every turn and therefore cannot mine or escape on tell a group of his compatriots com to his rescue and defeat the monster.  In this instance your Miners are spending their time rescuing, and not mining, whilst your competitor is merrily running up the score in his favour.Then there are chests.  Chests are gamble.  They can give you a huge advantage, give you a huge disadvantage, attack you (because they aren't really chests but rather monsters in disguise), or they can be worthless old tat.  Will you risk picking it up?  If it doesn't attack, you will need to carry it some distance to turn it in either at the surface or at a turn in location which you have discovered somewhere in your mine.There is much more to this game than what I have discussed thus far, but hopefully this will give you some feeling for the complexities as you play this game and plan your strategies.  As I stated in the beginning, it is deceptive, and there is much more to it than immediately meets the eye.  If you buy this game (an excellent value for money at the usual price and even better when it's on sale) then I wish you many hours of fun just as I have had, delving deeper!

												The page on this includes RPG and adventure in the description, but don't be fooled -- it's purely turn-based strategy.  You play on a variety of 2d side scrolling maps which each have a set number of turns for you to find and return the most loot for the dwarf king.  Maps are grid-based and you get to dig one grid deeper each turn.  You play as a team of five dwaves taking turns against 1-3 other teams.  You can choose a combination of scouts, miners and fighters to compose your team.  They all have different pros and cons: miners can carry more loot, but are weak to enemies and other players; scouts can move more grid spaces each turn, but are also weak; fighters can take down enemies but move fewer spaces and carry less.  Loot is either mined, dropped off slain enemies/players or found as artifacts laying around.  You must use a turn to deposit them at certain grids on the map before they count toward your score.Plenty of achievements, settings, looks nice and is fun.

Posted: November 25, 2013
												Delve Deeper is a light, entertaining turn-based strategy game in which each player commands a team of five dwarves in a race to gather as much gold and jewels as possible within the time limit. The rules are simple and straightforward, and the experience feels a lot like a board game as it plays out. Each turn, you will place a new section of tunnel, move each of your dwarves, and then watch as they fight monsters and gather treasure. Battles are basic RPG fare, and are handled automatically. The strategy elements come into play as you decide how to task your dwarves. Each dwarf can only hold a fixed amount of treasure, which must be returned to your base camp (or to a gnomish bank, for a fee) in order to be added to your score. There are also special relics which can be collected; these remain a mystery until they are turned in at camp, at which time they may give you a large boost in your treasure, provide the dwarf who was carrying it a boost to life, attack power, or speed, or even *subtract* points from your score in the case of cursed items.Strategic placement of tunnels is also important. The layouts of tunnels that may be placed become more restricted as you move from the highest 'dirt' level down through the 'stone' layer and into the 'deep'. If placing tiles carelessly, you might find yourself unable to reach a treasure-laden tunnel in the future. You also have the option of connecting monster-filled tunnels to your opponent's tunnel system in order to distract and delay them.I played several games of Delve Deeper against the CPU, each of which took 45-60 minutes to play out. I didn't see any way to save my progress during a game; all of the games I played were completed in a single session, but the lack of saving did discourage me from trying some of the larger maps.Positives:* Quick and easy gameplay provides bite-sized strategy without a major time commitment* Charming 16-bit-esque visuals and humorous writingNegatives:* No save functionality* A button to fast-forward through the computer's turn would have been nice

SPECIAL NOTE: After reading the steam reviews, if you still want this game, remember this: by going to "options", then "gameplay options", you can see an option to modify "game speed". Putting this up to 6 will make AI turns much faster and possibly much more bearable for you.Delve Deeper is a game that may fare much better as a tangible board game than as a digital video game. For example, games of Delve Deeper range from 15 to 25 rounds and can involve between two to four players (human or AI). However, all human players MUST be present at the same computer; this is what hotseat gaming means. Online multiplayer is not possible, though the developers have said this may be a feature in Delve Deeper 2.Each game can then last from 25 minutes minimum (at fastest game speed) to more than 1 hour, depending on game speed and number of players and monsters on a map. Players (and the AI which controls the monsters individually) will take turns moving their characters throughout the tunnels collecting ores and treasures.However, the turn-taking aspect WILL turn off players used to faster gameplay, especially if they intend on only playing against AI opponents. During your turn, you will have to move your dwarves individually. This is true for the AI dwarves, so having a maximum of three other opponent groups can drag out down-time between your turns. To make things worse, AI monsters are moved individually as well, and since they can easily outnumber the dwarves from twice to four times as much (which again depend on game settings), time is dragged out much much more.But all that aside, I enjoyed this game. I enjoyed the tactics involved when each player can add one tunnel per turn to benefit themselves or disadvantage others. I got excited when my dwarves raced against time and foes to deliver the riches before the final tally is made. And when everything goes to plan, I get oh so satisfied when enemies fall like dominoes and my dwarves snatch up treasure like flowers in a field.And as a sidenote, there is a collection mini-game of sorts: treasure chests contain textual descriptions of named treasures. These descriptions are then added to a "Royal Gallery" you can later peruse for your own very mild amusement.Ultimately, I recommend this game, but only in a particular circumstance: if you intend to have this game for parties. If you have a laptop and can set it up at party with little spillage of fluids, you and up to three other game-inclined friends can while an hour or two away, taunting and thwarting and triumphing as you move your groups of dwarves through the deep tunnels. Enjoy!

												Maybe it's the beard talking, but I've always liked dwarves more than elves. They don't care about harmonizing with trees and developing anorexia. They're a race of hairy, pudgy alcoholics, and if there's anything in fantasy lore I can relate to, it's going to be that.Delve Deeper(!) is a strategy game about mining. You command a team of five dwarves as they try to collect more treasure than any other team and win their king's praise. Each turn begins by placing a piece of tunnel into one of the unoccupied hexagons on the map to reveal any treasure within and build paths to yet more treasure (or to connect tunnels containing monsters to opposing teams' tunnels for your amusement and possible gain).Next, the dwarves are moved. Once a player ends their turn, that team's dwarves hang lanterns where they stand (as in Minecraft, light prevents monsters from spawning), and mine any nearby treasure, fight any nearby enemies, heal, or drop their treasure off, depending on what occupies the space alongside them.Delve Deeper has a pretty good sense of humor, most often taking the form of the Dwarven King's reactions to the dwarves' success or lack thereof. There's referential humor as well, but it thankfully doesn't feel as though it's being used as a crutch, as referential humor so often is.The gameplay is tactical, but easy to learn and most certainly fun. Everything from AI difficulty to monster and treasure frequency can be set to meet the player's needs. Aesthetically, the game is quite charming, considering it features a bunch of hairy, pudgy alcoholics. At $5, Delve Deeper is definitely worth a shot.

												The game gets boring really fast. While it has a lot of potential the potential is mostly lost in the clunky controls and repetative gameplay.The game consists of building up tunnels to "Delve Deeper" into a mountain. However a lot of your turns are spent either sitting on a mine or returning to base. You have three different classes, the scout who has more moves, the miner which has more inventory and the soldier which has more health. However since you end up using all your dwarves for just about everything, the you can't really take advantage of the class difference. Also since you can't trade between dwarves, you may a scout obtain soldier relics or something similar. The controls are by far the worst part of the game though. You select a hexagonal space by centering a giant hexagon in the center of your screen over it. It makes it insanely annoying to do anything. Also it's easy to make unintentional moves when selecting dwarves and moving your camera through the field.That being said, the game is rather challenging. Even the easy mode AI is a tough fight. Games are not extremely long so you have to make the most of every move. If you're looking to kill some time, you might try this game. However I would not recommend buying it for more then a $1 as it is not a very expansive game.
